user.biography: Inspiration and information about what works in education. Produced by the George Lucas Educational Foundation.

node.text:

node.title: Which Reading Strategies to Try, and Which to Ditch

node.text:
Distractions, confusing material, or an overwhelming amount of information can tax a student’s working memory. Here are tips that can help.

#WorkingMemory #ClassroomTips #TeacherTips #InTheClassroom #EducationResearch

node.title: How to Optimize Working Memory in the Classroom

node.text:
Getting to know all your students at the top of a school year can be overwhelming. One idea? Ask their families to tell you all about them, in a playful assignment called "In a Million Words or Less."

The Million Words activity originated with teacher Deb Bova on the MiddleWeb site in 2003, but has thousands of variations.

Link in bio. 

#FamilyEngagement #BackToSchool #StudentEngagement #BackToSchoolActivity #TeacherTip #TeacherTips

node.title: Getting to Know Your Students in a Million Words or Less

node.text:
As you return to school, think about starting a new routine or ritual that welcomes students to class every day. Not only will it help with classroom management, but students will be more focused, grounded, and ready to learn.

#WelcomeBack #BackToSchool #MorningRoutine #TeacherTip #TeachersOfInstagram

node.title: Starting Each Class With A Warm Welcome

node.text:
Educator Shana White discusses how she uses art to bring every student's identity into the classroom. "Identity portraits are a project that allows kids to express their own identities. It's a really big growth point for a lot of kids that they are able to be comfortable with who they are and recognize and respect the identity markers of anybody." 🖌

#Diversity #CulturallyResponsiveTeaching #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #Arts #ArtEducation

node.title: Exploring Perceptions About Identity Through Self-Portraits

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Inspi Inspirati ting in Nek me Open cultuu Creativity mine ral SOCIAL & EMOTIONAL LEARNING (SEL) Promoting Prosocial Behaviors in the Classroom'.

node.text:
When prosocial behaviors like kindness and empathy are nurtured in school, research shows it does more than make class a happy place, it also improves academic outcomes. “Each time we do a prosocial act, our brain releases chemicals that make us feel good, and those same chemicals enhance learning,” writes English teacher Cathleen Beachboard. ⁣
⁣
Here are three prosocial behaviors to teach and model in the classroom.⁣
⁣
1. Practice gratitude: Feeling gratitude over time increases a person’s overall mood, research shows. Set aside time regularly for kids to jot down things in a journal that they’re grateful for and encourage mindful reflection by asking them to reread previous entries. Or dedicate a special spot on your bulletin board for students to post notes of gratitude to each other. “Model the behavior by writing positive notes to students for specific acts, and posting the praise,” Beachboard suggests.⁣
⁣
2. Encourage kindness: Acts of kindness can increase compassion and lead to deeper classroom connections. Model kindness by giving authentic compliments in class and encourage students to deliver praise to peers. Ask students to write cards welcoming new kids to school. Or try a “jar of joy” project where students fill containers with positive messages, stories, and motivational quotes and then give them to friends or family members who need support or cheering up. ⁣
⁣
3. Develop empathy: Giving students opportunities to share vulnerabilities and dreams can “create bridges of empathy and understanding” between classmates and allow them to see how much they have in common, says Beachboard. Have students create a collage of positive memories, dreams, and aspirations. Or try identity portraits, collages that represent “who they are and their future goals,” Beachboard suggests. Display students’ projects in class and organize a gallery walk followed by a class discussion where kids share similarities and connections they noticed among the projects. 

#SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #ProsocialBehaviors #BackToSchool

node.text:
Research shows that some popular activities for reading instruction don’t actually result in more fluent readers—so we rounded up the most classroom-worthy ones.

#ReadingStrategies #ClassroomTip #TeacherTips

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on August 26, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, child, people sitting and text that says 'Pair Kids Up as Reading Accountability Partners TEACHERTIPS'.

node.text:
Like many teachers, Allie Thrower had her fifth-grade students fill out daily reading logs as part of their homework. But Thrower, now an elementary school continuous improvement coach, noticed that their log entries looked the same each day—they always read for exactly 20 minutes and not one minute more.

After discussing the topic with colleagues and digging into the research, she realized that “many parents and educators had strong negative feelings about reading logs,” Thrower writes. And a 2012 study of the practice found that “students with mandatory logs expressed declines in both interest and attitudes towards recreational reading in comparison to peers with voluntary logs, and attitudes towards academic reading decreased significantly.”

Thrower tried several alternatives before settling on reading accountability partners, a strategy where partners meet daily for 10 minutes to discuss the previous day’s reading. “The practice may seem simple, but the results have been impressive,” Thrower says, noting that pairings work best with students who will challenge each other academically and encourage each other emotionally.

Via mini-lessons, she helps students understand their roles, discusses how to hold peers accountable and how to be receptive to feedback, sets kids up with guiding questions, and circulates among the groups to make sure everyone’s on task.

#TeacherTip #TeacherTips #ReadingAccountability

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Powerful Community Building Ideas (across all grade levels) @edutopia'.

node.text:
These 9 community building ideas will help students in every grade feel like they’re part of the classroom community.

#TeacherTip #TeacherTips #CommunityBuulding #ClassroomManagement #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #BackToSchool

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Powerful Community Building Ideas (across all grade levels) @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '1. Shout-Outs With a shout-out, students can quickly celebrate their classmates' efforts and accomplishments. At any point during he class period, get the class's attention and ask who ha a positive shout- out for a peer. That way, praise becomes a part of the classroom culture, instead of emanating from the teacher exclusively. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '2. Friendly Fridays Ask your students to write a friendly, anonymous note to a classmate. Students can practice positive self-talk and explore storytelling while giving a peer a boost- a great way to end the week. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '3. Acts of Kindness Have student take notice- and celebrate-acts of classroom kindness For exampe when a student sees a peer tidying up in the classroom, they can post a thank-you note on a shared digital kindness wall." @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '当 4. Paper Tweets Create a bulletin board modeled on Twitter, complete with handles, bios, and at least three classmate followers, including a friend, an acquaintance, and someone students rarely interact with. Have students respond to prompts about their current mood or events in their lives Then their followers can respond by tacking or taping paper esponses underneath. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '66 5. Class Norms Have students brainstorm and discuss a set of working norms for the classroom-adjectives like "resourceful" and 'collaborative" and "considerate" that describe them as a community of learners. Use the discussion to determine the final set of norms. The practice can help every student feel a sense of belonging while building students' sense of personal responsibility and agency. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '開 6. Group Salutes At the beginning or end of a group activity, ask students to share something about themselves or express gratitude to the other participants to foster a sense of community Even a shared physical gesture, like a high five, can build a healthy sense of camaraderie and trust. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '7. Appreciation, Apology, Aha Το mark the end of class in a positive way, have students gather in a circle and share a little note of appreciation for a fellow classmate, a light bulb moment that emerged during group work, or an apology to rebuild trust. Model the behavior by sharing first, and then ask fo for volunteers. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '8. Roses and Thorns At the start of class, join your students in Ûh”ing one rose (something positive, like feeling good about an assignment) and one thorn (something negative, like feeling tired). The activity should take about 5 minutes. Awareness of a peer's emotional world can help foster empathy and build community @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on August 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says '9. Snowball Toss Have students write down a stressor on a piece of paper, crumple it up, gather in a circle, and throw their paper balls in a mock snowball fight; then have them pick up a snowball and read it aloud. When movement, fun, sharing, and discussion about stress are combined, connections among peers can feel more natural. @edutopia'.
